children.text: Okay, I need to translate these three Java programs into a single Fortran program that does the same thing as the sequence.

children.text: First, the first Java file (codeforces_369_B) reads several integers from input, processes them through the getPoints function, and outputs an array of integers.
children.label: code_analysis

children.text: The key is that the output of each Java program is the input to the next. So the first program's output is the input for the second, and the second's output is the input for the third. But in Fortran, I have to do this all in one program without intermediate I/O except for the first and last steps.

In Fortran, those are indices 4 and 5. So the starting idx is 5 (Fortran's n), and the condition is idx >= (n -k +1) = 5-2+1=4. So yes, the condition in Fortran would be idx >= (n -k +1). Therefore, the inner loop in Fortran would be:

do while (sk >0 .and. idx >= (n -k +1))

   ans(idx) = ans(idx) +1

end do

The outer loop continues while sk >0. But in Java, the outer loop is a while loop that runs as long as sk>0, and in each iteration, it starts at the end and moves backward until sk is exhausted or the indices are out of the last k elements.

children.text: The first element of ans is ans(1). Output 0 if it is 1, else 1. Now, coding this in Fortran. But first, note that in Fortran, arrays are declared with dimensions. So we need to read n first, then allocate the array. But since the first input is n, we can read it first, then read the rest.
children.label: high_level_plan
code_analysis

children.text:
Now, the code:

program main

   implicit none

   integer :: n, k, l, r, sAll, sk

   integer, allocatable :: ans(:)

   integer :: first_element

   !
children.label: code_analysis

children.text:
Read inputs

   read(*,*) n, k, l, r, sAll, sk

   !
children.label: code_analysis

children.text:
Allocate array ans of size n

   allocate(ans(n))

   ! Initialize ans to l

   ans = l

   ! Compute sAll and sk adjustments

   sAll = sAll - (sk + (n -k)*l)

   sk = sk - k*l

   ! Process sk

   do while (sk >0)

      integer :: idx

      idx = n

      do while (sk >0 .and. idx >= (n -k +1))

         ans(idx) = ans(idx) +1

         sk = sk -1

         idx = idx -1

      end do

   end do

   ! Process sAll

   do while (sAll >0)

      integer :: idx

      idx =1

      do while (sAll >0 .and. idx <= (n -k))

         ans(idx) = ans(idx) +1

         sAll = sAll -1

         idx = idx +1

      end do

   end do

   ! Get the first element

   first_element = ans(1)

   ! Output 0 if first_element is 1 else 1

   if (first_element ==1) then

      print*, 0

   else

      print*, 1

   end if

end program main

Wait, but in the sk processing loop, the variable idx is declared inside the loop.

Wait, but in Fortran, variables must be declared before any executable statements. So in the first loop:

do while (sk >0)

   integer :: idx

   idx = n

   ...

end do

This is allowed in Fortran 90 and later, where variables can be declared in blocks. So that's okay.

children.text:
program main

   implicit none

   integer :: n, k, l, r, sAll, sk

   integer, allocatable :: ans(:)

   integer :: first_element, idx

   !
children.label: code_analysis

children.text:
Allocate array ans of size n

   allocate(ans(n))

   ! Initialize ans to l

   ans = l

   ! Compute sAll and sk adjustments

   sAll = sAll - (sk + (n -k)*l)

   sk = sk - k*l

   ! Process sk

   do while (sk >0)

      idx = n

      do while (sk >0 .and. idx >= (n -k +1))

         ans(idx) = ans(idx) +1

         sk = sk -1

         idx = idx -1

      end do

   end do

   ! Process sAll

   do while (sAll >0)

      idx =1

      do while (sAll >0 .and. idx <= (n -k))

         ans(idx) = ans(idx) +1

         sAll = sAll -1

         idx = idx +1

      end do

   end do

   ! Get the first element

   first_element = ans(1)

   ! Output 0 if first_element is 1 else 1

   if (first_element ==1) then

      print*, 0

   else

      print*, 1

   end if

end program main

This way, idx is declared once outside the loops. That's better. Now, testing edge cases.
